Would anyone like to discuss further before moving onto the next topic?

Like if one kid notices another playing games and that becomes a distraction to him too even though he himself isn't doing anything wrong? How do teachers resolve disputes between classmates like that. Are there any thoughts so far on staff training concerning these incidents and handling situations effectively? We certainly need more guidance on what authority the instructors have over these kinds of circumstances, if any, right now we could end up with both classroom disruptions and possibly some confusion among teachers themselves regarding enforcement actions. I would think an established procedure clarifying teacher roles within each building would help minimize disputes among educators and offer them greater confidence addressing these matters on their own in real-time. Any ideas on establishing better defined parameters on all of that and especially for addressing disputes among students caused by alleged violations of this rule? Or maybe any plan yet devised for encouraging student self-monitoring here since part of education should involve fostering responsible digital citizenship skills, anyway? Has the district considered setting aside professional development hours for these topics at upcoming PD days for instance? If the intent behind these measures includes reducing negative impact on the learning environment while promoting self-regulation of technology usage patterns early enough for college and careers later down the line, then I believe it stands to reason there needs to be some sort of follow-up component in place ensuring educator familiarity with supporting students who struggle adhering to revised policies through these transitions.  We'll see less conflict overall once teachers understand our stance as administrators well enough themselves. A well-defined protocol explaining roles, responsibilities, and protocols surrounding PED oversight duties going forward seems critical for everyone involved--educators, kids, families alike--to buy into this.
